reasoning:
- Call: –1 (Partially Infeasible) because the claim bundles (i) thermodynamic stability of an A15 polymorph of Zr3Sb at 1 atm, (ii) its experimental discovery, and (iii) superconductivity. The only support is a single MLIP prediction with a sub-10 meV/atom margin relative to the known Ni3P-type phase, while experiments report only Ni3P at ambient and there is no evidence of superconductivity or discovery.
- Minima that must hold:
  1) A15 Zr3Sb exists at atmospheric pressure and is the thermodynamically stable polymorph (on/at bottom of hull). 
  2) It has been experimentally discovered/identified in that phase. 
  3) It is superconducting (Tc > 0 K) under ambient pressure.
- Evidence mapping:
  • Direct support: none for A15 phase existence/discovery or superconductivity.  
  • Indirect/proxy: CHGNet MLIP places A15 on the convex hull and slightly below Ni3P (≈6.8 meV/atom), within typical model uncertainty.  
  • Contradictions: Literature identifies Ni3P-type Zr3Sb as the ambient stable phase; no reports of A15 or superconductivity in Zr3Sb.
- Why –1 (and not 0): There is a concrete reason to believe the claim as stated is probably wrong—“discovered” and “superconductor” have no supporting evidence, and thermodynamic “stable A15” conflicts with established ambient-phase reports (Ni3P). 
- Why not –2: No fundamental impossibility is shown; near-degeneracy suggests A15 could be metastable or accessible under special conditions, and A15 compounds can be superconducting.
- Why not +1/+2: Critical elements (phase verification, thermodynamic dominance at ambient, and superconductivity) are unverified/contradicted.

Assumptions/limitations: Relies on one MLIP; no high-accuracy DFT/CALPHAD or experimental confirmation; superconductivity requires direct measurement or validated EPC calculations.
